title: Breaking: It Was an Incredible Week in New York
article_text: On Tuesday night, those seeking to snag a walk-in table at Balthazar were greeted with an unusual sign. Hung by the door at one of the most iconic French bistros to ever open in America was a note: “Closed for a Funeral.” Fair enough. And yet, if you peeked inside, those milling around were hardly in mourning attire, and there seemed to be quite a bit of celebratory champagne flowing, and hey…was thatAlec Baldwinlimping around? (More on this in a bit.) The “funeral” was actually a morbid front for a book party forKeith McNally,the restaurant’s owner, who has perhaps become better known for the acerbic wit on display in his relentless, very funny, improbably popular Instagram account. Bored during the pandemic, with his restaurants all shut down, McNally used the platform to reflect on his decades in hospitality, lash out at enemies, praise his famous friends, and wax poetic about the glory of living in Manhattan, the land of beauty and brains and financial power. The easy fluency of his captions led to a book. His memoir,I Regret Almost Everything,is a buoyant, frequently hilarious look at life after he had a stroke, a recovery story without your typical narrative, dotted with characters famous and not. It’s out this week, so McNally threw himself a book party. Scratch that—he threw himselftwobook parties, one of which fell on what might be the busiest night on the Manhattan calendar. It’s clear to basically anyone in the creative industries that this first week of May is the week-long stretch that makes this city’s cultural offerings the best in the world. The five-day feast kicks off with the maelstrom of pop-culture content creation that is the Met Gala, where the concepts of celebrity and fashion have a night at the museum. Then it’s off to hundreds of gallery openings throughout town, from the blue-chip temples in Chelsea to the younger upstarts in Tribeca. On top of that, there are a dozen art fairs, from the global behemoth Frieze to the Maastricht-based TEFAF to the smaller but potent homegrown fair Independent. There are also billions of dollars of art on display at the three major auction houses, ready for the sales to start next week. Into this, McNally unleashed his two-night self-fêting. The crowd Monday night seemed highfalutin’ enough that it was unclear how McNally might follow it…until I sawWoody Allen,whom McNally has unwaveringly supported on his aforementioned Instagram account, walk into the double doors on Tuesday. Upon entrance, I took a perch next toAmos Poe,the legendary New York filmmaker who’s known McNally since the ’70s and gets a mention in the memoir when McNally describes his favorite things about living downtown during that period: “theVillage Voice,CBGB, Spring Street Books, the Mudd Club, the Bleecker Street Cinema, the bars of Mickey Ruskin and the films of Amos Poe.” (Poe is also my father-in-law, but hey, it was a family kind of evening.) We started doing some people watching. It was like the ultimate murderer’s row of Gotham’s cultural elites: sitting next to Allen was the writerMichael Wolff,who’s out with his latest Trump book,All or Nothing.Down the table from them was Baldwin, who later explained that he had torn his meniscus, which sounds quite painful.Griffin Dunnewalked by, and galleristCharles Moffettwas sitting with Le Bernardin chefEric Ripert,and the restaurateurStephen Starrwas a table over.Tony Shalhoubwas standing by the bar with the comedianJeff Ross.McNally sat himself with only his family, and, later,Christy Turlington. But hey, it’s not all movie stars and models and funny guys—Vanity Fair’sLili Anolikwas there, along withCarl Bernstein,who was seated with the filmmakerAlexi Wasser.Bestselling author and chef andburgeoning stand-up comicPadma Lakshmi? Padma was there. My seatmate was the poetMax Blagg,a dapper Englishman who moved to New York in 1971 and is a repository of SoHo knowledge—he can still remember walking into the space we were currently inhabiting when it was a gigantic leather factory, when the whole neighbourhood was factories, when it was Hell’s Hundred Acres. After appetizers and before the entire room was served steak frites, actorRichard E. Granttook the podium to read some excerpts from McNally’s book. “I know you were all at the Met Gala, and like me, you’re all hungover,” Grant deadpanned, though at least one dinner guestwasactually at the party the night prior: Condé Nast global chief content officerAnna Wintour. Before he began reading, Grant invited McNally up to the podium. “This is a very sad night for me,” McNally said. “This is the first time I’ve ever not been given a check. So now I must leave!” The endless spree of happenings began Monday morning, with a press preview at The Met—the exhibition at the Costume Institute is unveiled to editors prior to the big party that night. The show’s a knockout. After the editors soon split for Sant Ambroeus—and one nearly knocked intoJeremy Allen White,with his cap on and AirPods in—it was on to pre-parties galore, followed by a red carpet that was especially loaded with VIP art stars this year.Rashid Johnson, Amy Sherald, Lorna Simpson, Eric N. Mack, Henry Taylor,Met trusteeJordan Casteel, Alex Da Corte, Cy Gavin(whose artwork is what you see emblazoned on the tent in all of the red-carpet photos) andArthur Jafa,resplendent in Fear of God, all made appearances, as did Gagosian directorAntwaun Sargent.There were after-parties—so, so many after-parties—but many of those in the art world opted to skip out in favor of pre-Frieze festivities, such as an event at a collector’s home in the Dakota honoringCecilia Alemani,who is curating the SITE Santa Fe International this summer. Also on Monday,Pierre Huygheopened an insane show at Marian Goodman, his first at the gallery in 14 years, withwork that was first shownat Francois Pinault’s Punta della Dogana in Venice last year. In attendance, somewhat surprisingly, wasThe Brutalistdirector and writerBrady Corbet—a confirmed Huyghe-head, we’re pleased to report.Raf Simonswas there to soak up the terrifying LED masks on mannequins. A dinner followed at Overstory, the private room on the 66th floor of a Deco skyscraper in the Financial District above Manhattan that allegedly has amazing views. But a cloud had consumed Manhattan, engulfing the space in a fog that seemed very much like…a Pierre Huyghe work. The vernissages and cocktail parties fanned out throughout Manhattan, but on Wednesday morning, the masses all assembled in the shadow ofThomas Heatherwick’sVesselto attend the pre-fair breakfast for Frieze New York, taking place, once again, at the Shed. Frieze is in a funny place right now. After a year on the block as part of previous owner Endeavor’s take-private by Silver Lake Capital, the fairannouncedlast week that superagent and Endeavor principalAri Emanuelwould acquire the fairs, which now include Expo Chicago and New York’s the Armory Show. The market sees Emanuel as a steady hand; he’s already owned the thing for a decade, and he’s pledged to keep CEOSimon Foxat the wheel. But rumors still swirled about how the New York fair would be at a different location come next year. As nice as it is to navigate a 65-booth outing, art fairs make money when hundreds of galleries pay booth fees, and Emanuel’s purchase valued the whole unit at $200 million. Time to up the profits, some say. Speculation aside, it was clear that the fair’s blue-chip denizens brought the goods this year. An obvious highlight was Gagosian’s booth featuring three works fromJeff Koons’sHulk Elvisseries, masterful cast bronze sculptures of Bruce Banner’s angry side enveloped by musical instruments.Anderson Cooperwalked by an hour into the fair, and then moved on to the David Zwirner booth, featuring a remarkable array of works bySherrie Levine,paintings aping Mondrian and Picabia, along with a big cast bronze caribou skull, and, again, Raf Simons.Tracey Eminwas on hand to see her big new painting in the White Cube booth. By the afternoon, things were getting quite scene-y. The writerKaty Hesselwas locked in conversation withCaspar Joplingand the artistEmil Sands,while a few feet away, the collectorPamela Joynerstepped off the elevator. I was standing outside when I saw something remarkable. A Rolls-Royce glided up to the entrance, and out cameMichael Shvo,the real estate tycoonlast seen by this columnist hanging out withPeter Marinoin Miami Beach, on an AirPods-in call, seamlessly talking as the Rolls drove away. (McNally’s habit of putting bad restaurant etiquette on blast?Yeah, he did that to Michael Shvo.) But was anything actually…selling? The art market’s been slumping for over a year now, and certainly the post–Liberation Day mood isn’t helping things. What’s a mega-rich lover of the arts to do in America? “All the art advisers are telling their clients this is a good time to buy, and all the financial advisers are telling them to keep all their cash on hand,” one observer noted. Maybe the quality of work on view was too good to not be snapped up. By the end of the day, White Cube found a buyer for the Emin painting at a price of £1.2 million. Word around the fair is that Gagosian sold one of the Koons sculptures for around $3 million. Karma’s booth, one of the more successful group show presentations at the fair, sold well: a small Gertrude Abercrombie work for $350,000, an oil painting by Richard Mayhew for $350,000, a painting by Manoucher Yektai for $275,000, and a painting byReggie Burrows Hodgesfor $175,000. Hauser & Wirth pulled off a pretty great flex. They brought works by gallery artists Rashid Johnson, Amy Sherald, Lorna Simpson, and Jack Whitten, all the subjects of grand-scale museum surveys at the city’s most prominent museums: the Guggenheim, the Whitney, The Met, and MoMA, respectively. And the gallery sold work by all of them, for prices as high as $1.2 million. “The crowd and conversations today have been incredibly upbeat,” said gallery presidentMarc Payot.“Perhaps most significantly, the energy this first day at the fair has been amazingly optimistic.” Usually by Thursday of an art fair week the powder’s spent, the collectors are jetting off to somewhere else—consider Art Basel Miami Beach, where, as I reported last year,people have started to bragabout leaving onWednesday,after the VIP preview opens, days before the public are even allowed to see the fair. The opposite happens in New York—Thursday is arguably thebusierday. TEFAF New York, an offshoot of the fair in Maastricht, launched an Upper East Side edition in 2016, and it’s come close to taking the crown from Frieze, at least in terms of prestige. All the city’s major galleries take a booth at the Park Avenue Armory. There, on Thursday afternoon, VIPs could peruse and buy new paintings byAnna Weyantat Gagosian, historical works by Ruth Asawa at Zwirner, and a wealth of earlyGeorge Condoworks on paper at Gladstone, including one that’s an homage to his friend Jean-Michel Basquiat. There’s also, of course, Basquiats, specifically at the Van de Weghe booth, whereChristophe van de Wegheis offering the artist’s 1984 portrait of Michael Patterson, his friend from the nightclub Area. Collectors such asTico MugrabiandAby Rosenwandered through, and while the oysters (top notch) were free in a nod to the fair’s Dutch origins, a single glass of bubbly set back guests nearly $50. The art was considerably pricier, still. At the Richard Green booth, the London gallery brought a towering 2009Stanley Whitneyto tie the whole thing together, along with a Frank Auerbach painting of his muse, Juliet Yardley Mills, seated. And over at Edward Tyler Mahem, there wasBarkley Hendricks’sSelina/Star,an incredible portrait that sold in 2020 for $937,500 at Phillips. The market in general may be softening, but not for everyone. Sources said the Hendricks had a price tag of more than three times the sale price at the auction five years ago. By Thursday evening, there was another art fair of sorts taking over the smattering of blocks between 10th and 11th Avenues in Chelsea. Already open through the week were painting bonanzas such asSalman Toorat Luhring Augustine,William Kentridgeat Hauser, a historical show of Warhol’s oxidation paintings at Skarstedt, and the boisterous, uncanny installations by the inimitable German artistRosemarie Trockel,in a two-part show between Gladstone’s Chelsea space and Sprüth Magers on the Upper East Side. In Chelsea on Thursday, Zwirner opened its brand new building on 19th Street withnewwork by itsnewestmarket star,Michael Armitage.But it was still a bit overshined by the spectacle two blocks away:Takashi Murakami’s first show with Gagosian in the neighborhood since 2014, a series of epically sized paintings based on Utagawa Hiroshige’s prints from the 1850s that inspired the Impressionists toward Japonisme. On Wednesday, more than 24 hours before the official opening,Larry Gagosianhimself strolled through the show, with a flurry of his staffers giving private tours to hand-selected clients. By Thursday night, a line to get into the gallery snaked down the block. For the dinner celebrating the opening, well, it could only be at one place: Jean’s, the extremelyboom boom aesthetic–coded sleaze-tastic eatery on Lafayette Street in the space that once housed Butter,thescene-forward restaurant of the aughts,asRichie Akivacan attest to. A few days ago, Jean’s hostedA$AP RockyandRihanna’s Met Galaafter-party, and now it was Murakami’s party. On the menu was shrimp cocktail, cheeseburgers, and steak tartare. A pretty serious number of heavy-hitter collectors and curators were in attendance. Gagosian directorNick Simunovicgave a heartfelt toast about Murakami’s show, raising a glass to the artist, who was sitting with Gagosian. After the dinner, I went to my apartment to let the dog out, and me and the ridgeback—who is named Butter, not after the Akiva-era spot, but a fun coincidence—strolled down the dog-friendly stretch of Great Jones Street, past the fire station, then found our way back to the dinner, a few blocks from my place. What I encountered outside of Jean’s was remarkable: crowds of people with Murakami posters and merch and handbags and albums he designed, hoping Murakami himself, in town for just a few days, might sign them. Paparazzi was present. It was beautiful mayhem, and all part of the best week for culture in New York. Have a tip? Drop me a line atnate_freeman@condenast.com.And make sure yousubscribe to True Colorsto receive Nate Freeman’s art-world dispatch in your inbox every week. title: King Charles Sends Pope Leo XIV a Private Message of Congratulations
article_text: A king who has always described himself as a peacemaker, as he did during a 2020 speech in Davos, could not remain indifferent to the first words spoken byPope Leo XIVfrom the balcony of St. Peter’s Basilica: "Peace be with all of you!" On Friday, from Buckingham Palace comes confirmation thatKing Charles III,Supreme Governor of the Church of England, sent a private message to the new pontiff, elected only Thursday to the Chair of Saint Peter. Newly elected Pope Leo XIV, Robert Prevost addresses the crowd on the main central loggia balcony overlooking St Peter's Square on May 08, 2025 in Vatican City, Vatican. White smoke was seen over the Vatican early this evening as the Conclave of Cardinals took just two days to elect Cardinal Robert Francis Prevost, who will be known as Pope Leo (Leone) XIV, as the 267th Supreme Pontiff after the death of Pope Francis on Easter Monday. "The King has sent a private message toPope Leo XIV, congratulating him on his election as the 267th Pontiff and Bishop of Rome. His Majesty sent his, and Her Majesty’s, most sincere good wishes for his Pontificate," reads the official note. A congratulatory message that also carries with it the signature ofQueen Camilla. The royal couple hadmet with Pope Francis in April, during the last day of his state visit to Italy, before leaving Rome and heading to Ravenna. It wasa private meeting with Francis, while the official visit to the Vatican, which was supposed to include a moment in the Sistine Chapel, now the scene of Leo XIV's first mass, had been postponed. But not canceled: According to sources close to the Palace, the visit will be rescheduled in the coming months, now with the new pontiff. In this handout image supplied by the Vatican on April 10, King Charles III and Queen Camilla meet Pope Francis during day three of their State visit to The Republic of Italy on April 09, 2025 in Vatican City. Their Majesties will attend a State Banquet at the Palazzo Quirinale, hosted by The President. He is the first pope to come from the United States. Pope Leo XIV, born Robert Francis Prevost, was born in Chicago in 1955, to a father of French and Italian descent and a Spanish mother. His path was then marked by a long stay in South America, between missions in Chulucanas and Trujillo, Peru. It was an experience that left a profound imprint on his pastoral vision, as was also evident from his first speech, delivered in Italian and Spanish (and without a single word in English). From Spain, meanwhile, came official congratulations fromKing Felipe VIandQueen Letizia: "We congratulate Cardinal Prevost on his election as the new pontiff, Pope Leo XIV. His call for peace inspires us, encourages us and reflects the deep desire and feelings of the Spanish people." Words that recall once again the common thread of this new election: peace. A theme that seems to run through the first international reactions, such as that ofPrince Albert IIof Monaco, who expressed in French, the official language of Monegasque protocol, his "fervent prayers for the greatness of the pontificate" of Leo XIV. And it is precisely at the Vatican, in mid-May, that Pope Leo XIV will return to welcome Spanish Jubilee brethren, including representatives of the Esperanza de Málaga, a community to which he is particularly attached, following his 2007 visit to Colegio Los Olivos. An American pope, a British king, European sovereigns: the echo of Leo XIV's election crosses borders and continents, like a shared call to dialogue and reconciliation. “Peace be with you, unarmed and disarming. Help us build bridges to be one people” – Pope Leo's first words struck a chord. title: A Close-Up Look at Kristi Noem’s Attempts to Glamorize MAGA and Affirm Trumpian Codes of “Femininity”
article_text: Department of Homeland Security SecretaryKristi Noemnever fails to make headlines. Whether posing for photos at anEl Salvadorian prison wearing a $50,000 Rolex watchor regalingreaderswith the tale ofkilling her family dog, Noem has made a point to keep all eyes on her. After her purse—which contained $3,000 in cash—was stolen over Easter and subsequent arrests made,she claimedthe suspect, Mario Bustamante Leiva, had been in the "country illegally for years.” And then there's just the way she presents herself. Celebrities know how to deploymethod dressingfor press tours for blockbuster releases, and Noem is bringingthe same sort of publicity-hungry fashion energyto thepolitical theater, through an apparently endless supply of cowboy hats,pilot-inspired leather jackets, and baseball caps, plus a heap of ultra-conventional gender performance for good measure.Donald Trumpis asilver screen executivefor theinfluencer-age, so it's logical that the supporting cast is also camera-ready, and Noem has made her roleindelible. When Noem first came onto the scene in 2010 during her run for Congress with a fluffy, feathered lob, à laKate Gosselin, she wouldn’t have been out of place in any corporate office setting. Fast forward to the current MAGA era and herhair cascades in waves, the lipgloss is high-shine, and the lashes are full, lookingFox News-readyat any moment. The ease with which Noem costumes herself for far-right political activism has earned her the nicknames Cosplay Kristi and ICE Barbie—and shows a sincere awareness of the strategic power of aesthetics, playing to the tastes of one President Trump. See: her lengthy vlog documenting hercosmetic dental proceduresto “fix her smile” when speculation swirled around whether she might be tapped for the VP spot. (Travelers United sued herfor “undisclosed advertisement” which it claimed violated a consumer protection law; a judgedismissedthe complaint last May). It's true the style choices and physical appearances of female politicians have been, historically, more heavily scrutinized than their male counterparts. Not least by Trump himself. Referring to Noem when the twospoke at a Ohio rally in 2024: “You’re not allowed to say it, so I will not. You’re not allowed to say she’s beautiful, so I’m not going to say it.” Noem’s hyper-feminine look, polished to apageant-y sheen, is by no means an accident, particularly in light of thecomments Trump has made regarding the appearancesof those close to him and his apparent preference for women to“dress like women.”Like any cultural moment there is a certainvisualstyle guide to being MAGA—the New YorkTimesrecently offered ananalysis of exactlywhat that means—and Noem stands as an exemplar of it. Here, a close look at how Noem’s aesthetic shifts have lined up with her public actions. Whether dressing up as anelectricianand ahighway patrolmanto sell the idea of working in South Dakota in local ads or donning accessories that gained her the “ICE Barbie” nickname, Noem has taken the notion ofpolitical theatreto it's most surface degree. Noem has distilled the look of “Trump's kind of woman” by often wearing some variations of the American flag colors, long waves with a middle part and highlights—at times calling to mind not only the women on Fox News but also those of the Trump family tree. Last year saw Noem on the Trump rally circuit, a book tour of sorts as shetried to make a molehillof the mountain of oddities in her memoir released later in the year, and to top it off she was barred fromseven of the nine reservationslocated within South Dakota. While her one-woman-show didn't land her the VP position she was able to bid her gubernatorial post farewell and step into the role of Secretary of Homeland Security with a fresh balayage. Noem's national notice grew in leaps and bound in 2021 as shebannedtransgender girls from sports via executive order,fielded a scandal overhandling of her daughter’s real estate appraiser license, and enjoyed CPAC praise as she lauded South Dakota's pandemic response, of course despite the data sayingotherwise. One of Noem's earlier interactions with Trump centered on his visage as he'd shared he always dreamed of being carved into Mount Rushmore. Reminded of the commentby the Guardianin 2022 (January 6 insurrection was just the year prior), Noem said, “I don’t think we’re adding any faces to Mount Rushmore any time soon. It is pretty special just the way it is." With Trump's first turn at the Oval Office fresh in mind and a second run on the horizon, Noem's transformation kicked into higher gear as speculation swirled around whether she might get the VP tap. Four Congressional terms later, Noem staged her homecoming with a bid that saw her become the first woman elected governor of South Dakota,a narrow win at 51 percent of the vote. As a member of the Ways and Means Committee in her final term in the House, she helped pass the Tax Cut and Jobs Act of 2017— emphasizing provisions in the bill as addressing needs ofworking mothersin her state. When Noem was detailing the importance of closet space to NPR in 2015, it had nothing to do with her current rotation of costumes. Instead she and fellow lawmakers on Capitol Hill were working by day and sleeping in their offices by night—in Noem's case on apull-out. Bolstered by the 2010s girlboss era, a fresh, more structured take on theKate Gosselinasymmetrical haircut and abachelor’s degreein political science from South Dakota State University, Noem focused her efforts on the 2012 Farm Bill,imploringthen-PresidentObama's support. Signed into law January 2014, the bill included a “sodsaver” provision meant to incentivize conservation of prairie land and protection of wetlands. At a moment when the Republican party was particularly cognizant of being perceived as a “party of southern white men,” Noem was touted as a breath ofdiverseair for the GOP amid a greaterwaveof Republican women running in 2010. Her narrow defeat of four-term incumbent Rep.Stephanie Herseth Sandlinlanded her immediate notice for her freshman term. Also notable at the time was herdisavowingfull-scale dismantling of governmentdepartments—not so much the case today. Noem's firstadfor her Congressional bid invoked a down home sensibility with a full denim getup and prominent belt buckle; connecting her support for her family ("I came home to help run the family farm.") to her campaign promises. title: Even Cubs Fans Are Excited About Da Pope, a Sox Fan and Chicago’s Hometown Hero
article_text: On an unseasonably chilly and windy Thursday afternoon in Chicago, a dozen or so people stood outside Wrigley Field, their phones drawn to snap a picture of the iconic marquee. It was celebratingthe new pope,Robert Prevost,henceforth known as Leo XIV, who was (incorrectly, it seems) rumored to be a Cubs fan. One advertisement after another flashed across the screen—for Home Run Inn pizza, for Jewel-Osco, for the Wendella boat tour—but nothing about the Chicago-born pontiff. “It feels like we’re waiting for the white smoke,” I said to the guy standing next to me. “I was just thinking the same thing,” he replied as a frigid breeze blew across Clark Street. “I’d rather be in Rome.” This content can also be viewed on the site itoriginatesfrom. Incidentally, I had just recently gotten back from Rome; my wife and I happened to be there when Pope Francis passed, the day after Easter. And when we went to the Vatican that evening to pay our respects like the good—albeit lapsed—Catholics we are, we found ourselves being interviewed by an Italian television reporter. “Do you want the next pope to be an American?” she asked. An American pope, at this moment in America? No, that’s all right, we said. AChicagopope, though? Well, that’s a different story. Leo—who holds dual United States and Peruvian citizenship—was born at Mercy Hospital on Chicago’s South Side, grew up in the far south suburb of Dolton, and studied at Chicago’s Catholic Theological Union while teaching math and physics at St. Rita on the southwest side, where it is common to identify not by neighborhood but by parish. (My stepdad went to St. Rita. My wife was part of the first class of girls to graduate from its rival, Marist. I went to public school in the suburbs and am still trying to wrap my head around all these feuds.) Those Chicago roots could give Prevost a “unique perspective,” saidJames Robinson,dean of the University of Chicago Divinity School. “I think it’s really incredible that he comes from here,” Robinson told me. “Chicago people like to talk about this as the City of Broad Shoulders, the Windy City, but it is also, in my opinion, one of the most interesting religious cities in the country and the world.” Hyde Park—home of the University of Chicago, as well as the CTU, where Prevost studied—is “the center for the mixing of [religious] traditions,” Robinson said, adding that that’s “something that’s needed, I think, more than anything in this increasingly divisive world.” Michael Patrick Murphy,director of Loyola University’s Hank Center for the Catholic Intellectual Heritage and a senior lecturer at the school, had dinner with Prevost last summer in west suburban Wheaton while they were working on a project together. “We had a great couple hours,” Murphy told me. “He was such a great guy.” They exchanged emails; Murphy still has Prevost’s cell number saved in his phone. Now the 69-year-old is the leader of the world’s 1.4 billion Catholics. “It’s mind-boggling,” Murphy said. “Chicago’s gonna eat this up.” Indeed, the new pope’s Chicago roots have already elicited waves of jokes—“No ketchup on the Eucharist!” one friend texted in our group chat. But Leo’s election will be about “more than the optics and spectacle” of having a new pope, Murphy said. Chicago isone of the most Catholic citiesin the country, one where you might hear older Catholics speak reverently about when Pope John Paul II came to town in 1979. Do Leo’s roots portend another papal visit to Chicago? Perhaps. If he does come, though, he may not take the Cubs up on their offer to sing “Take Me Out to the Ballgame”; his brothersaysthe pontiff, as a native South Sider, is a lifelong fan of the White Sox, a team thatwould likely welcome all the prayers it can get. “A pinstripes White Sox jersey with his name on it and a hat already are on the way to Rome,” the team said in astatement. “And of course the pontiff always is welcome at his ballpark.” This content can also be viewed on the site itoriginatesfrom. title: Rita Hayworth’s Heartbreaking Vanishing Act: “She Looked at Me and Said, ‘Who Are You?’” Her Daughter Tells VF
article_text: It was supposed to be Rita Hayworth’s epic return to the silver screen. Instead, the Hollywood icon’s role in the 1972 WesternThe Wrath of Godbecame the last moviegoers ever saw of her. As she faded away in the years that followed, a heart-wrenching disease would come into greater focus. Hayworth herself would not be spared from the worst of it, but countless others around the world would be helped by her story. It’s a bittersweet legacy, but one that continues to this day. Rita Hayworth with her daughter Yasmin. Hayworth had developed early onset Alzheimer’s, which began manifesting when she was only in her 40s. It robbed Hollywood of one of its most luminous golden age stars well before her time, but the diagnosis and her family’s decision to go public with her condition helped raise awareness about the pathology of Alzheimer’s disease at a time when not even doctors knew much about it. “I think it helped the world,” saysPrincess Yasmin Aga Khan,the daughter of Hayworth and Prince Aly Khan, who were married from 1949 to 1953. “It helped people in general. I’m still frustrated though, because people don’t want to talk about it still.” As the honorary vice chair of the Alzheimer’s Association, Khan has dedicated her life to helping patients and their families contend with the disease. The annual Rita Hayworth Gala, she says, has raised in the neighborhood of $90 million for medical research and patient support over its 40-year history. But it was too late for Hayworth herself: She had no idea what was happening as her mind began to deteriorate when she was still in her prime. Born Margarita Carmen Cansino, Rita Hayworth was the daughter of a Spanish father and an American mother of Irish descent, both of them dancers. As soon as she could walk, she was taught to dance, and was performing professionally with her family by the age of 12. “She first gained the attention of motion picture producers when she was featured with her father in the floor show at the famous Agua Caliente Hotel,”The Sunday Starof Washington, DC, reported in a 1939 profile. She left that Tijuana resort for Los Angeles when she was 16, and was probably happy to go. In the 1989 biographyIf This Was Happiness,Barbara Leamingwrote that Hayworth had been abused by her father. Hayworth ended up in the clutches of another domineering figure. The imperious Harry Cohn, who ran Columbia Pictures, signed her as a contract player and controlled and manipulated much of her career. Cohn worked with Edward Judson, a salesman turned pseudo-manager, to shape Hayworth into a screen performer. Judson took his involvement in her life even further, and the two developed a romantic relationship, despite the objections of her family. “Eduardo protested loudly that Judson was as old as he himself, her own father,” veteran Associated Press journalist Bob Thomas recounted in his 1967 biographyKing Cohn. “But Margarita was unconcerned. She was intrigued with the balding, round-faced Judson and his talk of how she could become a big star.” They married in May 1937, when she was 18 and he was 40. She appeared in a flurry of movies over the next several years. She has been credited under the name Rita Cansino for some time, then Americanizing it to Hayworth. In 1939, director Howard Hawks cast her as Judy, the former lover of Cary Grant’s character in the South American romantic dramaOnly Angels Have Wings. Hawks reportedly advised the studio chief to keep Hayworth under wraps so audiences would be caught off guard by her stunning screen presence. She was so beautiful and so charismatic that he considered just the sight of her a spoiler. “If you’re smart, you won’t do anything with her until the picture comes out,” Hawks said. “No other movies, no publicity, nothing. Then you’ll know what you’ve got.” As it turned out, Cohn had a bona fide star. Hawks was right. Hayworth stole her scenes in the drama, and was groomed to be a leading lady. Her biggest star-making moment came at 22, when she was paired with Fred Astaire in 1941’sYou'll Never Get Rich,as two Broadway dancers who fall in love. It was such a crowd-pleaser that Cohn ordered up another film, 1942’sYou Were Never Lovelier,to keep the duo dancing and the box office cash flowing. That movie remains one of her daughter’s favorite films. It came out seven years before she was born, but when Khan wants to remember her mother as she once was, separate from the frail figure she cared for until her death in 1987, she watches that one. “There’s my mom.You Were Never Lovelier—light as a feather,” Khan says. “She was amazing, beautiful. She was like a diamond in the sky.” Hayworth was not only Cohn’s breakout star, but her iron-clad contract with him also meant she could be a profitable asset to lend to other movie studios. During one such arrangement, she struck up a romantic relationship with Victor Mature while performing with him in the 1942 20th Century Fox filmMy Gal Sal. Judson was enraged. “She charged that Judson demanded $30,000 to get out of her life; if she didn’t pay, he threatened her with bodily harm and exposure to public contempt and ridicule,” Thomas wrote inKing Cohn. She refused. “In the end, Edward Judson got his $30,000—from Harry Cohn,” Thomas reported. And Hayworth got her first divorce. By then, she was on her way to becoming one of the brightest stars of Hollywood’s golden age. Moviegoers swooned for her. Newspapers nicknamed Hayworth “The Love Goddess.” American GIs carried cutout photos of her from aLifemagazineprofilewhen they fought overseas in World War II, making her one of the most popular pin-ups of the era. After the war, she became a literal bombshell—the atomic devicetested at Bikini Atollin 1946 was affixed with a sultry photo of her fromEsquiremagazineand stenciled with the name of her most famous role—the title character from a film noir thriller released that year:Gilda. She was not flattered. Hayworth reportedly despised being associated with a weapon of mass destruction. “Rita almost went insane, she was so angry,”said Orson Welles, who was married to her from 1943 to 1947. “She wanted to go to Washington to hold a press conference, but Harry Cohn wouldn’t let her because it would be unpatriotic.” Gildacreated its own shockwave. Her entrance in that film sees her rising from below the camera with a luxurious flip of her hair and a dazzling smile. The 1994 filmThe Shawshank Redemptionfeatures the prisoners going wild when they watch the scene, and the effect was similar with moviegoers all across the country at the time. (The full title of theStephen Kingnovella that inspired the film wasRita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption, since the main character uses one of her pinup posters to hide the escape tunnel he is digging in his wall.) While married to Welles, Hayworth struck up a secret romance with herGildacostar Glenn Ford, an on-again, off-again relationship that would endure for the rest of their lives. She was married five times, but never to Ford—although they lived next door to each other in Beverly Hills for many years. Hayworth blamed the upheaval in her personal life on her “Love Goddess” image. InKing Cohn, Virginia Van Upp, who wrote many of Hayworth’s movies and produced her most famous film noir, recalled Hayworth saying: “It’s your fault. Every man I know has fallen in love with Gilda and wakened with me.” Hayworth remained a Hollywood powerhouse for years to come—comparable to theAngelina JolieorJulia Robertsof her day. Exotic and beautiful but relatable. Among her most memorable roles was another film noir, the 1947 thrillerThe Lady From Shanghai,which Welles directed. Their marriage broke apart soon after, but she and Welles remained cordial. His final public words were about her. In a 1985 interview onThe Merv Griffin Show,recorded just hours before he diedfrom a sudden heart attack, he called Hayworth “one of the dearest and sweetest women that ever lived.” She was still alive at this point, but long gone from the ravages of dementia. Welles suggested she had been defamed over the years by those who didn’t know better. “I never believed she was a drunkard. I didn’t know about Alzheimer’s disease, but I believed that something like that was wrong with her.” Leaming’s biography of Hayworth took its name from something Welles told her, recounting that “Rita told him, ‘You know, the only happiness I’ve ever had in my life has been with you.’” The remark stunned Welles, who thought their relationship had been fraught and difficult. “If this was happiness,” he told Leaming, “imagine what the rest of her life had been.” Hayworth and Orson Welles on their way to filmLady From Shanghai In his final interview with Griffin, Welles concluded: “I was lucky enough to be with her longer than any of the other men in her life, and she is a dear person. She was a wonderful wife and an extraordinary girl in every way and I’ve never heard anybody—anybody—who sounds like an enemy.” He then amended that: “But she used to throw stuff around the house a little bit when she’d think about Harry Cohn.” Hayworth’s work was marked by endless clashes with the studio boss over which roles she should do and her volatile love life, which Cohn thought generated bad press. He raged over her haircut inShanghaiand her switch from auburn red to icy blonde according to Thomas’sKing Cohn. They also feuded over her wardrobe choices, her travel, and countless other minor matters. “He felt like he owned me,”Hayworth toldjournalist John Hallowell in 1968. Her marriage to Prince Khan had ended after four years, which was about the limit for most of her relationships. Then she was briefly married to singer Dick Haymes from 1953 to 1955. The Argentine singer was plagued by debt, alimony, unpaid taxes and was battling deportation. She was locked in acontract lawsuitagainst Columbia Pictures, part of her ongoing war against Cohn in the years before his death. Tensions in the marriage led to an explosive argument at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles in August 1955, where Haymes was a performer at the Cocoanut Grove. Broadway columnist Earl Wilson reported that Hayworth “charged Haymes had ‘used violence’ and indicated the breakup was irreparable.” Florabel Muir of theNew York Daily Newsreported that the clash was partly over her plans to end the lawsuit against Columbia. “Dick opposed her peace move. He insisted that any settlement of Columbia’s contract squabble with Rita must include a pact for him as producer of the siren’s films.” She and Haymes divorced, and Hayworth agreed to return to the studio to shoot two more films to end any further litigation—although Cohn was already scheming against her. She headlined the love-triangle comedyPal Joeyfor the studio in 1957, playing a former burlesque dancer turned gold-digging widow who falls for an unscrupulous lounge singer played by Frank Sinatra. Sinatra agreed to give her top billing, in deference to her years of work at Columbia. Kim Novak got third billing as the impoverished, struggling dancer who was nonetheless pure of heart. InPal Joey, Hayworth was the flame-haired devil on Sinatra’s shoulder, and the blonde, wide-eyed Novak was the angel. But Novak’s big break at the studio came about due to the furious battles Hayworth had with Cohn. Cohn decided that Columbia Pictures was too reliant on Hayworth, and he was on the search for a new signature leading lady when he signed Novak, who was previously known as “Miss Deep Freeze” from a popular refrigerator ad campaign. In a 1962 profile of Novak, syndicated Hollywood columnistLloyd Shearerreported that Cohn, “faced with the problem of an obstreperous Rita Hayworth, decided to groom someone—‘anyone,’ as he put it, ‘to replace that ingrate.’” Cohn’s reputation as a bully was well-known throughout Hollywood, so Hayworth was regarded as justified in her defiance. According to Thomas’sKing Cohn, when the studio chief died in 1958, comedian Red Skelton remarked to the 2,000-plus attendees at his funeral service: “Well, it only proves what they always say—give the public something they want to see, and they’ll turn out for it.” But soon, the narrative shifted: Maybe Cohn was right about Hayworth. Rumors about Hayworth’s volatile temper circulated throughout the industry. Filmmakers and crew workers privately grumbled about how difficult she was, and how unprepared she sometimes seemed. Her daughter says the family didn’t watch her mother’s movies, but as a child she became suddenly aware that mom was somebody important because of all the photographers who swarmed them when they disembarked from a cruise ship. And then there were mother’s famous friends. “I remember Frank Sinatra, Hermes Pan the choreographer,” Khan says. When she was around nine years old, she remembers moving with her mother to the desert while she shot the 1959 WesternThey Came to Cordurawith Gary Cooper. Hayworth was about 40 at the time. “Already I think she was having problems with that film,” Khan says. “I didn’t see it on set. I just saw behavioral changes at home.” Her mother usually could maintain herself in public, but sometimes the cracks showed. “I didn’t see it on our little trips except for maybe vaguely. There was some drama on the Spanish steps, and I can’t recall what the drama was, but she was very upset with us, with the whole situation. I wish I had a better memory of those days. Sometimes you just want to block it out.” As Hayworth’s health worsened, so did her personal life. The once stalwart star became increasingly unable to stand up for herself. Her final marriage was to screenwriter James Hill, an uncredited producer on the 1958 dramaSeparate Tableswho recruited her to play the lead role: a divorced woman trying to reunite with her ex-husband (Burt Lancaster). Hill and Hayworth were married from 1958 to 1961, and their relationship was reportedly just as volatile as her last. In his 1995 autobiography,In the Arena,Charlton Heston recalled meeting them both for the first time at a dinner party, which he described as “the single most embarrassing evening of my life.” Hayworth with James Hill, 1958. “[Hill] began the evening by relentlessly heaping obscene abuse on her. She was rapidly reduced to a helpless flood of tears, her face buried in her hands; the rest of us simply sat stunned, witnesses to a marital massacre,” Heston wrote. “I didn’t know either of them, but I was strongly tempted to slug him anyway. If he hits her, I thought, that’s it. Looking back, I really wish I hadn't waited.” They departed when Heston’s wife, Lydia, came close to tears. “I’m ashamed of walking away from Miss Hayworth’s humiliation,” Heston said. “I never saw her again.” After she and Hill divorced, Hayworth never married again. But she was not fully alone. HerGildacostar Glenn Ford, lived next door to her, and they had worked together several times over the years. They had always remained close, and in 1965 she costarred with him again inThe Money Trap, a thriller about a cop who goes bad and decides to rob some thieves who’ve stolen half a million dollars, with Elke Sommer as the temptress who leads him astray. “Third-billed, playing the cop’s washed-up former girlfriend, was a woman my father had known and worked with for over a quarter of a century, his longtime friend and sometime lover, Rita Hayworth,”Peter Fordwrote in his 2011 biography of his father,Glenn Ford: A Life. “It had been nearly 20 years since Rita and Glenn had burned up the screen inGilda. Now, in 1965, Glenn was still playing male leads, but Rita—and her career—had declined. It was one of the inequities of the Hollywood system that the male stars seemed to go on and on with their careers while the leading ladies had to struggle for good parts once they reached 40.” Hayworth and Glenn Ford inThe Money Trap The Money Trappublicist Bob Crutchfield said in the book: “I was at his house a lot in those years, and Rita of course lived next door. She was always calling Glenn or would just appear through the gate in the backyard. Sometimes champagne bottles would precede her arrival. She’d throw the bottles toward the skylight that covered the atrium. Glenn finally put up chicken wire or something to stop the bottles coming through. He was always tender and sweet with her, no matter how she acted.” Those close to Hayworth believed she was succumbing to alcoholism. Looking back, her daughter believes it was a way to self-medicate. Hayworth didn’t understand that there was a deeper problem. “She had no idea,” Khan says. “She was drinking quite a bit, with bursts of anger and then sweetness. She was frustrated and of course I was frustrated. And then I was away at boarding school for a good part of my life. I’d go back to California and I’d see the different stages.” Khan’s elementary school days were spent at the North Country School in upstate New York in the Adirondack Mountains, then high school in Massachusetts at the Buxton School. The time away from home highlighted the changes in her mother that seemed gradual to others closer to her. “She would come visit. But already I noticed something was wrong. She wasn’t quite right,” Khan says. It was obvious to those in the Hollywood community too. Work opportunities dried up for Hayworth. The bombshell had become a ghost. “There was loss of memory, there was unhappiness, there was fear,” her daughter recalls. “In Beverly Hills, at our house, she would think that there were people outside, and she’d call the police. And then they’d arrive, and of course there was nobody there. There was quite a bit of paranoia.” In 1968, John Hallowell set out to land an interview with the increasingly elusive star, and began trying to make connections at a Hollywood event showcasing a PR company’s new roster of talent. He found that the film industry had largely written her off. “One of the biggest-deal press agents in the world, Warren Cowan, was making the scene with all the new and beautiful people, when someone tapped him on the shoulder and asked: ‘Do you represent Rita Hayworth?’”Hallowell wrotein his lead. “Cowan turned, pained. ‘Of course not. We only representtodaypeople.’” When he finally did make contact and secured an interview, her representative warned him: “She’s very shy. She doesn’t see people much.” Hallowell described his encounter at her Beverly Hills home, lined with a wall of hedges, and said the star answered the door herself. “She stands a little unsurely in the doorway,” he wrote. “At first it’s all yes and no. She looks down at her hands, trapped. The house is so empty you can hear the silence.” He likened her to the fading silent film star played by Gloria Swanson in 1950’sSunset Boulevard. Hayworth complained to him about the TV antenna on her neighbor Ford’s roof, spoiling her view. After so many of her studio battles, the reporter asked if she thought contemporary stars have more freedom. “Honey, I have so much freedom, I don’t work,” she replied. Hallowell wrote: “And she starts laughing, an old, wide open Rita laugh that sends her hugging herself into a wicker chair. ‘Sorry, I just broke myself up.’” Hayworth told him a story about being lectured by a film producer, who warned her that if she got a certain unspecified role that she couldn’t change any of it—an indication of her reputation for being “difficult” on set. Hayworth said she ended the meeting over the indignity. “I could have used that part,” she said. “I take care of myself. Nobody gave me this house. And I don’t get alimony and all that jazz." That’s when the press agent signaled Hallowelll: “Time to leave” On a second visit to her home, the writer described Hayworth as even more erratic, scribbling circles in red ink on a notebook while she spoke to him, then crumpling the page. She lashed out at Harry Cohn, theorizing that he’d “purposely come up with a lousy picture” to spite her, and called him “a monster” while pounding her fist on a table. Other times she would ramble, or express non sequiturs. “Slowly, fading out with the last afternoon light in her dark red hair, Rita Hayworth walks you to the door, not saying anything now,” Hallowell wrote in his closing line. “But outside, leaning against the doorway, she all of a sudden summons up another great screen goddess: ‘Ava is smart. She’s living in Europe. Ava knows.’” Her daughter, then only 18 and a freshman in college, had become alarmed by her mother’s strange behavior. “When I was at Bennington in Vermont, she would call me and she would just repeat the same question, and I was very concerned,” Khan says. “And thank goodness there were people who cared about her in Beverly Hills—her lawyer, for one. And so I kept an eye on her, but it was frustrating for me because I was at school.” “Rita Hayworth to End Holdout; She’ll Clown With Carol Burnett,” announced the headline to an Associated Press report from February 1971, written byKing Cohnauthor Thomas. “I had seen Carol do a take-off onGildaon her show, and I thought it was hilarious,” Hayworth said in the article. “I sent her a wire saying so. Then in a couple of interviews I mentioned that if I ever did television, it would be with Carol Burnett. She suggested it, and I agreed.” Hayworth and Carol Burnett perform in 1971. Hayworth’s daughter recalled her mother being intimidated by her return to the spotlight. “She was hesitant about television,” Khan says. “She was aware that she was losing.” In an interview with columnist Joan Crosby before shooting the show, Hayworth seemed to be managing expectations. “I’m getting a little scared,” she said. “Probably I’ll just stand there and laugh and look at the camera and say, ‘I forgot my line.’” Instead, herguest spot onThe Carol Burnett Showwas a surprise success. Hayworth played herself in one sketch, having lunch with her agent (played by Harvey Korman) while Burnett gawked at her as an intrusive fan. Most of Hayworth’s work was merely reacting to Burnett’s over-the-top gushing, and when she does have lines, it appears as though she’s reading them from the menu she’s holding. Hayworth seemed more confident in a later sketch when she and Burnett danced and sang a silly song about their “Mutual Admiration Society.” There may have been a clinical reason for this. Studies have shown that music can be helpful for those with Alzheimer’s disease. “Musical memory is partially spared in patients with [Alzheimer’s], despite severe deficits in episodic memory,” says a 2022National Institutes of Healthreport. “Patients can learn new songs, encode novel verbal information, and react emotionally to music.” Khan experienced that firsthand with her mother, even as the disease deepened in the years that followed. “Often she would perform when I was at home,” she says. “ She was trained as a flamenco dancer with her father, so she would put the music on and play the castanets that she loved. She twirled around the living room. That brought her joy, the dancing.” Several months later, she appeared on a July episode ofThe Merv Griffin Showthat was billed as a special tribute to her. Then in September, she made another sketch comedy appearance onRowan & Martin’s Laugh-In. Some of the jokes seemed to toy with her questionable reputation. In the intro, hosts Dan Rowan and Dick Martin bring her out to fulfill her request to read a Henry Wadsworth Longfellow poem on network television. Hayworth opens the book, then falls silent. The awkwardness builds. After a moment she snaps it closed, and says: “Thank you. Boy, that Henry W. sure can write a poem.” (The joke is that she always intended to read it to herself—not that she was confused.) Another sketch featured her doing slapstick as an aging film star named Laura LaMont, who is falling down drunk and perpetually crashing into furniture. She only pulls herself together when she thinks cameras are running, but when her new chauffeur accidentally says “cut,” she reverts to her drunken state and face-plants into a cake. Once again, her strongest performance was a song. She sanga bawdy numberwithLily Tomlinas they sipped tea and dished about the attractiveness (or lack thereof) of the show’s impresarios. Thanks to Merv, Carol, andLaugh-In,Hayworth suddenly seemed viable again. “Rita’s Back!” theDaily Mirrordeclared in a bold-faced headline from January 24, 1972. This was accompanied by an image of Hayworth with her mouth pursed in steely resolve, staring into the middle distance with her lavish mane of hair tucked beneath a flat-brimmed black hat. “Rita Hayworth, Hollywood sex symbol of the 1940s, is back in business as a movie star,” the article stated in a report that was intended to be enthusiastic but today reads as insulting. “Give or take a few wrinkles, she clearly still packs plenty of appeal…. Miss Hayworth, who costars with Robert Mitchum, is working in Mexico on her comeback film,The Wrath of God. It’s described as an adventure drama—for the leading lady, too, perhaps.” Hayworth inThe Wrath of God. At that point Hayworth hadn’t appeared in a feature film in two years, and she’d only made a few sporadic big-screen appearances during the decade before. InThe Wrath of God, Mitchum would play an outlaw priest in the untamed frontier of Central America who carries a gun in his bible and a knife in his crucifix. Hayworth played Senora de la Plata, the mother of a silver miner (Frank Langella) who is targeted with assassination. “She was by then finished in pictures and the word was that Mitch had insisted on her, possibly for old time’s sake,” Langella wrote in his 2012 memoirDropped Names. Despite her lively TV comedy appearances the year before, Hayworth struggled even with this small role. The knowing look in her coffee-colored eyes, so piercing in her early roles, had been blunted. The quick delivery of lines that made her one of the most playful of femme fatales had grown stiff and stilted. Her costars were the first to notice. “On the set, she is a total pro. Ready to go, eager to do her best. But the lines won’t come,” Langella wrote. “No matter how hard she tries, she can’t retain the simplest phrase. In our first scene together, I approach her at prayer in a church and ask, ‘Why are you here?’ Her line is ‘Because God is here.’ But she can’t do it. Take after take, she is unable to retain those four words.” Her struggles dragged on so long that the crew became restless, with some of them quietly mocking her inability to say a simple phrase. “Finally a man is laid down on the floor at her feet,” Langella wrote. “Action is called. I ask, ‘Why are you here?’ He whispers, ‘Because God is here.’” She quickly repeated the line. “The crew bursts into cheers and applause,” Langella wrote. “Rita beams like a little girl who’s just been crowned Miss Snow Queen, completely unaware the cheers are jeers.” After learning of her Alzheimer’s diagnosis years later, Langella felt regret about his own behavior toward her: “The jokes about her are lewd and cruel and for years after, I too would be guilty of reenacting the scene for friends at her expense.” Langella and Mitchum joined forces to make sure she would get to set on time in the mornings, and the crew developed ways to compensate for her memory problems. “In all her scenes, large placards are put next to the camera and her lines are written out in huge block letters,” Langella recalled. “It becomes agony for her to try to hold on to what little she can, and an embarrassment to face each daunting day. But she does face them, and she does make it through.” The Wrath of Godwould not be her comeback. It would be her farewell, and an unworthy one at that—reviled by critics, ignored by ticket-buyers. Langella himself described it as “an embarrassing disaster.” “She was angry a good part of the time,” her daughter says. Hayworth’s final years of awareness were plagued with outbursts and confusion. “There are those with Alzheimer’s who can be mild in their personality and pleasant. And then there are those, like my mother, who raged. And I think alcohol helped to blossom that rage,” Khan says. Hayworth had always fought so hard for her independence—against her father, against her husbands, against her studio chief. The part of her that remained could not stand to acknowledge she was losing control. Rita Hayworth and Yasmin Khan in New York City, 1984. “To take the car keys away was major,” Khan says. “After I graduated from Bennington, I went home and we went for a car ride somewhere, and it was on Sunset Boulevard. She was driving and she swerved over and hit the curb. It was like, ‘Oh my gosh, this is a disaster.’ It was panic. And I had to tell her to get out of the car and go to the back seat. That was the beginning of the end of her driving.” Her family still didn’t know exactly what was afflicting her, other than the alcoholism. “I got a diagnosis in ’81 by a psychiatrist in New York City, but before that, there was no diagnosis,” Khan says. “I don’t know what her doctor in Beverly Hills was thinking. It was very difficult. In London, they had carried her off the plane and she was in a drunken state of confusion.” The world saw those photos. The 57-year-old looked disheveled and miserable as she was escorted from the aircraft. “‘Unwell’ Star in Airport Riddle” was the headline in theManchester Evening Newsin January 1976. The article said she had been drinking and became disruptive on the flight from Los Angeles, and it took two airline workers 30 minutes to carry her out. That gave paparazzi plenty of time to line up their shots. In March 1977, an even more grim headline hit the press: “Rita Hayworth alcoholic, mentally ill; gets guardian.” The Associated Press reported that a California court had ordered a temporary conservator to oversee her well-being after Dr. James Miner of Hoag Memorial Hospital in Newport Beach testified that the 58-year-old was “gravely disabled as a result of mental disorder or impairment by chronic alcoholism.” Hayworth was officially no longer in control of her own life, but the blame was still being primarily placed on booze. Her daughter moved her to New York and began getting her treatment there. Even then, the public remained judgmental. In response to the court order,Los Angeles Timescolumnist Harriet Van Horne wrote: “We have all had friends or acquaintances whose days have ended in disgrace of confinement. Because we have glimpsed them occasionally on that miserable downward slope, the inevitable crack-up doesn’t shock us. But Rita Hayworth! How could she, who was so dearly loved, love herself so little?” In the 1979 bookThe Decline and Fall of the Love Goddesses, authorPatrick Aganquestioned why Hayworth had failed to mount a successful comeback after her TV comedy appearances years earlier, and pointed not to her awkward performance inThe Wrath of Godbut to a follow-up appearance on Griffin’s TV show that became disastrous. “It became all too apparent to both Griffin and the studio audience that she was simply too drunk to continue, and was escorted offstage during a station break,” Agan wrote. “Sensitive, shy, and no longer secure in the beauty that had made her a goddess, Rita had tried to compensate for her insecurities by drinking in the dressing room, and it proved her undoing.” No consideration of a degenerative illness was made. It was only later, when Khan got a proper diagnosis for her mother and decided to share it publicly, that those judging Hayworth realized how wrong they were. By then, it was too late for Hayworth. She would never know vindication. She could not accept apologies. She was already gone. Khan set her mother up in an apartment next to hers and visited her frequently. Once again, songs would enliven her. “I would put music on and she was in the chair, and she’d be very peaceful and smiled,” Khan says. “For some TV programs or movies, she would say, ‘Oh, I’ve seen that movie. I know that movie, right?’” Sometimes she was even in the movies she watched.You Were Never Lovelier,the 1942 musical that Khan counts among her favorites, was one that brought back memories for Hayworth. “She talked about how she loved Fred Astaire,” Khan says. One day, mother and daughter were standing before a full-length mirror. Hayworth would live for several more years, but this was the last that Khan would ever see of her. “She looked at me and she said, ‘Who are you?’” her daughter recalls. “She didn’t know who I was. But she knew that she was safe, which is most important.” Hayworth’s long goodbye had ended. The rest of her days would pass in silence, staring. “She was not verbal. She could not feed herself. I fed her, the nurse fed her. She put the food in her mouth and she couldn’t swallow,” Khan says. “We had to stimulate under her chin in order for the reflex to swallow. It was very, very difficult. It is just a very slow and painful decline. In 1985, Khan gave birth to her son, Andrew, and would bring the baby to visit his famous grandmother. “I’m not sure that she actually knew, but you always hope and pray and wish that she would know that that’s her grandson,” Khan says. “Being a caregiver, I was very concerned, of course—wanted her to live as long as possible. But it was difficult because I don’t know that she was aware.” Rita Hayworth died on May 14, 1987, at the age of 68. Even before her mother’s death, Khan began helping others confront the disease openly, without the shame or stigma that befell her mother, or the confusion and misdiagnosis that delayed her care. Among the Alzheimer’s Association’s initiatives is ahelplinefor family members who need advice—800-272-3900. It was a resource she and Hayworth never had. The nextRita Hayworth Galais scheduled for May 10 in Chicago, a day before Mother’s Day. The event is already sold out. “We have incredible people involved—caring, generous, amazing. We’re so fortunate,” Khan says. This was her whole reason for revealing her mother’s diagnosis when she finally understood it fully. “It was something that I didn’t know about,” Khan says. “I wanted to share it with people.” By the end, Rita Hayworth no longer knew who she was. But the world has never forgotten. title: How an Orgasmic Meditation Group Sparked a Troubled Federal Case
article_text: “I am here to tell the story of my sister,” a woman says as she addresses the camera. “That she was in a cult, and her experience of going through that.” The mood is somber, and a title card appears to explain thatAyries Blanckdeclined to be interviewed for the 2022 Netflix documentaryOrgasm Inc,“out of fear of reprisals by OneTaste,” a wellness company devoted to a meditative concept of female stimulation. Instead, her sister,Autymn,reads aloud from her journals. “I remember being told not to go to the hospital,” Blanck wrote, claiming that she was beaten and sexually assaulted in the course of her activities at the organization. She was told, she continued, that her shaking and vomiting were part of her orgasm. The journal entries provide the opening for a kind of archetypal cult-documentary third act, with the other shoe just about to drop. They are also, as Brooklyn federal prosecutors pursuing a criminal case against OneTaste leaders recently acknowledged, to some degree falsified. Nicole Daedonecofounded OneTaste in San Francisco in 2004. Over the following decades, a period during whichalternative health ideaswere reaching mainstream saturation, she became the face of orgasmic meditation, a mindfulness practice in which a partner, typically a man, strokes a woman’s clitoris for 15 minutes. In press coverage of OneTaste, the wordcultappeared intermittently. Participants sometimes lived together in communes devoted to Daedone’s teachings. Untila 2018 Bloomberg reporton the company was published and a criminal investigation began, though, she was largely treated with a shifting mix of fascination and skepticism. At that point Daedone underwent a late-2010s arc familiar to any observer of the streaming era’scult-documentary boom. The year afterOrgasm Incwas released and OneTaste became known to Netflix’s vast audience, prosecutors charged Daedone and her longtime head of sales,Rachel Cherwitz,with a count of forced labor conspiracy. They claimed that, among other forms of coercion and surveillance, the women exploited their employees’ and participants’ histories of sexual trauma to obtain control over their time, money, and willingness to perform sexual acts. Daedone, who sold her stake in OneTaste and stepped down as CEO in 2017, and Cherwitz, who left the company in 2018, have pleaded not guilty. In March, with a trial date soon approaching, the government made a jarring concession. Blanck’s handwritten journal entries, which formed central evidence in the case, had been physically copied from an electronic file created years later. Lawyers for Daedone and Cherwitz had for months been arguing that the diaries were fabricated for Netflix’s purposes, noting that the streamer paid Blanck’s sister $25,000 for use of her archival materials. The prosecutor who had been vouching for the authenticity of the journals left the case. (The government has had a full turnover of its prosecutors over the period between indictment and trial.) The evidence was thrown out, and Blanck was no longer set to be called as a witness. (A spokesperson for Netflix declined to comment. Blanck’s sister and a lawyer who has represented Blanck did not return requests for comment. OneTaste paid Blanck a $325,000 settlement in 2015, but has denied that she was beaten or sexually assaulted in connection with her employment or courses she took.) The trial’s opening arguments began on Tuesday, but Daedone had already been on the offensive. Aside from OneTaste suing Netflix for defamation—the complaint was dismissed by a judge, but OneTaste is appealing—Daedone has posted videos of her supporters, a sizable group of women, walking in unison outside the Brooklyn courthouse where she is being tried. She has conducted a spirited PR campaign; following the prosecution’s backtracking on Blanck’s journals, aDaily Mailheadline declared that the case “teeters on the brink of collapse.” In several interviews, including one I conducted with her last month at Organic Erotic, a home goods store in Harlem affiliated with the orgasmic meditation community, Daedone has vowed that she will testify in her own defense. “First they call you a kook, then they say you’re a danger to society,” Daedone said, comparing the treatment she had received to that ofRobert F. Kennedy Jr.“Then they dig into your history, and then they move into legal. And it was like, Wow, that’s what happened.” In 2009 a Berkeley couple wrote toTheNew York Timesregarding a splashy story the paper had just published about OneTaste.Elana Auerbachhad been a resident of the company’s original commune and, as she stated in her initial account to theTimes,had given her self-image and internal compass over to Daedone. In a letter to the editor, Auerbach and her husband went further. “We found the environment manipulative, unhealthy and disempowering,” they wrote. “Group-think and the threat of being shunned were used to coerce people to adopt the dominant viewpoint.” Auerbach has maintained this conviction up until the present day, including in an appearance inOrgasm Inc.In January, she published an essay inThe Sunday Times,writing of Daedone, “I realized I had become her servant, just like the others.” To prepare for a OneTaste ritual that involved lying naked on a table for an audience, she wrote, she needed to sign up for a course that cost $15,000. (A company spokesperson told theTimesthat Daedone and OneTaste “firmly dispute” Auerbach’s portrayal, “which appears to be meticulously designed for dramatic effect.”) Such accounts, in their broad view of Daedone’s power over OneTaste participants’ sexuality and finances, are at the core of prosecutors’ case. The indictment invokes an alleged pattern of “abusive and manipulative tactics” that entailed absolute commitment to Daedone and rendered members “emotionally, socially and psychologically dependent on OneTaste.” Daedone explained as we spoke that orgasmic meditation is an attention-training practice that uses sexual energies but is not itself sexual. She saw her work in a lineage with yoga, Buddhism, and psychedelics—sources of previous American panics that won acceptance as time passed and attitudes loosened. Relaxed and gregarious, she held unflinching eye contact and flitted freely between references to Schopenhauer and Andrea Dworkin. At the peak of her success, Daedone was neither in the shadows nor extraordinarily prominent. In the world of celebrity-adjacent wellness, brushes she had withGwyneth PaltrowandKhloé Kardashiancould be viewed as akin to table stakes. Her rise has always involved a degree of intrigue in her backstory. In her 20s, she told me, she worked as a stripper for a time at the recommendation of an academic friend who was doing so. Around the same period, she has said, she learned shortly before her estranged father’s death that he had cancer and that he was in prison after being convicted of child molestation.Orgasm Incincludes footage from a Daedone talk in which she discussed her reaction to the revelation. “I never took on the idea that he was a bad person,” she said. “I took on the idea that he was just so expansive and fourth-dimensional that he couldn’t confine himself into the arbitrary laws of the third dimension. That was his only crime in my mind.” When I asked if there were moments when she felt OneTaste had veered off course, Daedone said that some of her commentary in this vein, in its accommodating analysis of male culpability amid the #MeToo movement, “was a place where I really misread the room,” though it had seemed to her a given that “women have power in agency and that we aren’t inherently in a form of subjugation.” The case against OneTaste has attracted attention from some specific frequencies on the ideological spectrum. In February, the libertarian magazineReasonpublished a lengthy deconstruction of the charges, accusing prosecutors of relying merely on “salaciousness, scandal, and the all-too-familiar sense that female sexuality is something to be suppressed and controlled by the state.”Matt Gaetz,at a moment whenDonald Trump’s supporters have become increasingly fluent in discussions of “lawfare,” bemoaned FBI overreach in a recent segment on his One America News show—and weighed in on orgasmic meditation. “I posit no theory on the efficaciousness of these purported remedies,” Gaetz said. “But I don’t know—after being poisoned, lied to, and deprived of my rights by Big Pharma, I’m probably more open-minded about alternative naturopath therapies than I was years ago.” OneTaste had the “seeming makings” of a cult, Daedone conceded, “except for a nefarious intention,” but she thought that common perception had been shaped by the term’s loose use. “Once you use those words, then people’s cognitive ability goes down.” Daedone’s publicist,Juda Engelmayer,who was sitting by her side, chimed in. “Ultra-Orthodox Judaism, it’s cultish,” he said. “Not a crime.” Daedone tracked Engelmayer down in 2018 after she read a news story that was relatively favorable toward his clientHarvey Weinstein.The day before we spoke, Engelmayer had attended the opening of the producer’s retrial on rape and criminal sex act charges. (Weinstein has pleaded not guilty and denied all allegations of sexual misconduct against him.) He has also recently represented Ozy Media cofounderCarlos Watson,who was sentenced in December to nearly 10 years in prison for defrauding investors, but saw his term commuted by Trump after Engelmayer facilitated a sequence of connections to the president’s“pardon czar.” ANew York Timesreporter has been trailing Engelmayer for a profile, and the spokesman observed that his work on behalf of embattled public figures had hit a turning point in recent years. “Slowly but surely,” he said. “TheJohnny Depptrial withAmber Heard,I think that might’ve broken the cork.” Under their bail conditions, Cherwitz told me in a separate interview, she and Daedone were not allowed to be in the same place at the same time. Before she was indicted, she said, the government had approached her through her attorneys as a potential victim. “It’s like they were coming to brainwash me,” she said, “or somehow coerce me to fit into their narrative.” At 19, Cherwitz moved to Israel and practiced Orthodox Judaism for five years. Later, she said, she was diagnosed as anorgasmic and couldn’t find suitable help within the medical community. At an Iyengar yoga class, a teacher told her about OneTaste. “I’m losing so badly in my life right now, I should try this,” she remembered thinking. “And it spoke to me in a pretty deep way.” In an October court filing, the government laid out its position in more detail. The overall portrait centered on a persistent advocacy for more sex, including instances in which the defendants allegedly taught employees to engage in sexual acts that they found uncomfortable or repulsive as a means of expanding their horizons—“ensuring that the OneTaste participants would continue to have sex with strangers for Daedone’s financial benefit.” According to prosecutors, Daedone and Cherwitz directed women to have sex with wealthy potential clients. (In her opening statement on Tuesday, Daedone’s attorneyJennifer Bonjean—who also represents Weinstein, among other high-profile men accused of sexual misconduct—said, “Grown people made grown decisions they don’t want to stand by.”) The accusations could be construed as allegations of sex trafficking, which had initially been a focus of the FBI’s investigation into OneTaste. But as lawyers for Daedone and Cherwitz noted in a reply filing, the government did not bring any charges of that severity. Engelmayer has been emphatic about communicating to reporters that the case against OneTaste, to his and defense attorneys’ knowledge, marks the first time that forced labor conspiracy has been charged as a stand-alone count, without an accompanying crime that would typically represent an instance in which the conspiracy—an agreement to commit the crime—was enacted. (A spokesperson for the Eastern District of New York’s US Attorney’s Office declined to comment.) WhenFrank Parlatofirst read about OneTaste in 2018, he was convinced that something was amiss. It was what looked like familiar territory: For a brief period beginning in 2007, Parlato worked as a publicist for NXIVM, then a little-known self-help organization. A decade later, after turning his attention to reporting for his website, the Frank Report, he played an early role in revealing that his old bossKeith Ranierehad operated a sex cult. (In 2020, Raniere was sentenced to 120 years in prison for racketeering and sex trafficking, among other crimes.) In addition to his NXIVM and OneTaste coverage, another recent Parlato fixation is his claim thatJerry Sandusky,the former Penn State football coach convicted of serial child molestation, was railroaded. After Engelmayer approached him about OneTaste, Parlato told me, “I made a very serious news-gathering effort in an investigation to determine whether they were being fairly or, in my opinion, unfairly prosecuted.” In his coverage, he has described the case in his hyperkinetic house style, writing, “Parlato Lives Rent-Free in Prosecutors’ Heads, While Actual Evidence Lives Nowhere.” (Prosecutors have claimed OneTaste paid Parlato $20,000 per month for his coverage. Parlato has written that OneTaste retained him to investigate the prosecution. Engelmayer said the agreement lasted a few months and that Parlato continued writing about the case afterwards.) Parlato proposed to me that the OneTaste case amounted to “criminalizing regret.” He compared participants’ lodging allegations to going to Harvard and later realizing that the education hadn’t been as valuable as expected. As he sees it, the charges, brought in the same jurisdiction as those against Raniere, are simply an attempt at bringing about another high-profile cult case, or, as he described it, “NXIVM 2.0.” For their part, 20 Brooklyn prosecutors appeared at a recent pretrial hearing in a show of support. The prosecutor who led the investigation of Raniere,Moira Penza,who left the US Attorney’s Office in 2019, told me that she found a few aspects of the case against Daedone and Cherwitz unusual. The government had pursued a novel strategy, lost a key witness and evidence at the finish line, and swapped out all its prosecutors on the case. “Keith Raniere wasn’t doing TED Talks and appearing in South by Southwest and talking to Gwyneth Paltrow,” Penza said, describing Daedone’s media profile. Penza emphasized that she had no reason to think that her former office had acted improperly in pursuing the charges, with its trial strategy still to be seen, or that it could not secure a conviction. Jurors wouldn’t necessarily wonder, “Oh, well why didn’t they charge this the way they charged NXIVM?” she said. She also thinks that since Daedone’s initial rise, “there are more people who are very skeptical of the way wellness can be used to exploit women.” Still, Penza said, “As a former prosecutor, I can tell you you don’t want to be trying a case with those things stacked against you.” For the last several years, Daedone told me, as she dealt with the media and legal fallout around OneTaste, she has been focused on preparing for her trial and keeping up her meditation practice. On social media, she has been weighing in on pop-culture discussions of women’s sexuality, including those surroundingBianca Censori’s displays of nudity andBonnie Blue’s pornography stunts. “I am not a martyr,” Daedone insisted, but she understands her struggle in a broader sense, as something “more telling about the culture than it is about me in a lot of ways.” As we discussed the circumstances leading up to her indictment, I asked if it was fair to characterize OneTaste participants as seekers. She had an instant reaction and a partial objection: The term had a diminishing connotation. They were “almost invariably someone who had touched something,” Daedone said, “or had a sense that something more was possible.” This story has been updated.
